titles.title: The surprising origins of the word “lesbian” - Diane J. Rayor

questions.question: Who was the ancient Greek poet celebrated for her intimate and personal poetry about love, passion, and longing?

options.label: A
options.text: Sappho

options.label: B
options.text: Ovid

options.label: C
options.text: Homer

options.label: D
options.text: Aristophanes

questions.question: What instrument did Sappho typically play while singing her songs, which also gave rise to the term "lyrics" in poetry?

options.label: A
options.text: Lyre

options.label: B
options.text: Harp

options.label: C
options.text: Flute

options.label: D
options.text: Drums

questions.question: What is the origin of the term "lyrics" in poetry, and how is it related to Sappho's performances?

options.label: A
options.text: From the Greek word for "song"

options.label: B
options.text: From the name of a famous poet

options.label: C
options.text: From the instrument "lyre" that Sappho played

options.label: D
options.text: From the Latin word for "verse"

questions.question: How would you describe the tone of Sappho's poetry, particularly when she writes about love and desire?

options.label: A
options.text: Formal and objective, reflecting the societal norms of ancient Greece

options.label: B
options.text: Intimate and personal, offering a unique perspective on love and desire

options.label: C
options.text: Sarcastic and humorous, poking fun at the conventions of love

options.label: D
options.text: Angry and bitter, reflecting a sense of frustration and disillusionment

questions.question: What were the social norms regarding marriage and relationships in ancient Greece, and how did they differ for men and women?

options.label: A
options.text: Men and women were free to choose their partners, and same-sex relationships were widely accepted

options.label: B
options.text: Everyone was expected to marry and have children, but men were allowed to have extramarital relationships

options.label: C
options.text: Only men were allowed to have homosexual relationships, while women were expected to be chaste

options.label: D
options.text: Women were allowed to have multiple husbands, while men were expected to be monogamous

questions.question: Why do you think Sappho's poetry was neglected or destroyed by monks and Christian leaders?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was considered too secular and did not conform to Christian values

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was deemed too erotic and licentious, and was seen as a threat to moral standards

options.label: C
options.text: Because it was written by a woman, and was therefore considered inferior or unimportant

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was too old-fashioned and no longer relevant to contemporary society

questions.question: What is the current state of Sappho's surviving work, and what are the prospects for recovering more of her poetry in the future?

options.label: A
options.text: We have all of her poems and songs, and there is no need for further recovery efforts

options.label: B
options.text: We have around 50% of her total known work, and more is likely to be discovered in the future

options.label: C
options.text: We have less than 10% of her total known work, but new technologies and discoveries may lead to the recovery of more poetry

options.label: D
options.text: We have none of her original work, and it is unlikely that any will be recovered in the future

questions.question: How do you think the historical rumors about Sappho's life, such as her falling in love with a ferryman, reflect the attitudes of the time towards her and her work?

options.label: A
options.text: They show a deep respect for her work and legacy, and a desire to understand her as a person

options.label: B
options.text: They demonstrate a neutral and objective view of her life, and a commitment to factual accuracy

options.label: C
options.text: They reveal a misogynistic and homophobic bias, and a desire to marginalize or erase her

options.label: D
options.text: They indicate a lack of interest in her personal life, and a focus on her poetry alone

questions.question: What does the phrase "I say someone in another time will remember us" suggest about Sappho's hopes for her legacy?

options.label: A
options.text: She wanted to be forgotten after her death, and did not care about her legacy

options.label: B
options.text: She hoped her work would be remembered for a short time, but did not expect it to endure

options.label: C
options.text: She believed her words would endure across time, and would continue to resonate with readers

options.label: D
options.text: She was unsure about the impact of her poetry, and did not know if it would be remembered

questions.question: Why do you think Sappho's poetry continues to resonate with readers today, despite being written over 2,500 years ago?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it deals with universal themes of love and desire that are still relevant today

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a product of its time and reflects ancient Greek culture, which is still studied and admired today

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a rare example of ancient Greek literature, and is therefore valuable for historical and scholarly purposes

options.label: D
options.text: Because it has been extensively studied and analyzed by scholars, who have helped to keep it alive and relevant

titles.title: The rights you might not realize you have - Shannon Odell

questions.question: What is the primary reason for young plaintiffs suing their governments around the world?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase funding for environmental policies

options.label: B
options.text: To promote sustainable agriculture practices

options.label: C
options.text: To hold governments accountable for inaction on tackling climate change

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce taxes on environmental policies

questions.question: What is the name of the international document that outlines human rights, adopted by the United Nations in 1948?

options.label: A
options.text: Universal Declaration of Environmental Rights

options.label: B
options.text: Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR)

options.label: C
options.text: International Treaty on Climate Change

options.label: D
options.text: Global Pact on Sustainable Development

questions.question: According to human rights advocates, what is the connection between human rights and the environment?

options.label: A
options.text: Human rights are unrelated to environmental issues

options.label: B
options.text: Environmental protection is a secondary concern to human rights

options.label: C
options.text: The principles of the UDHR depend on access to healthy ecosystems

options.label: D
options.text: Human rights only apply to social and economic issues

questions.question: What is the estimated number of countries and jurisdictions that have enshrined the right to a healthy environment into national legislation?

options.label: A
options.text: Over 50

options.label: B
options.text: Over 100

options.label: C
options.text: Over 150

options.label: D
options.text: Over 200

questions.question: What was the outcome of the Colombian Supreme Court case in 2018, filed by young plaintiffs?

options.label: A
options.text: The court ruled in favor of the government, dismissing the case

options.label: B
options.text: The court ordered the government to pay compensation to the plaintiffs

options.label: C
options.text: The court delayed the decision, pending further review

options.label: D
options.text: The court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs, finding the government was legally obliged to reduce deforestation and greenhouse gas emissions

questions.question: What is the predicted consequence of mass extinction due to climate change, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A 10% loss of global biodiversity by 2050

options.label: B
options.text: A 25% loss of global biodiversity by 2100

options.label: C
options.text: A 50% loss of global biodiversity by 2150

options.label: D
options.text: A 75% loss of global biodiversity by 2200

questions.question: What is the significance of the UN General Assembly's recognition of the right to a clean, healthy, and sustainable environment in 2022?

options.label: A
options.text: It marks a major setback for environmental protection efforts

options.label: B
options.text: It is a non-binding resolution with no impact on national policies

options.label: C
options.text: It demonstrates a growing global commitment to align human rights with environmental protection

options.label: D
options.text: It is a redundant recognition, as the right is already widely accepted

questions.question: How many human rights-based environmental cases have been filed across the globe, as of the summer of 2023?

options.label: A
options.text: Over 100

options.label: B
options.text: Over 500

options.label: C
options.text: Over 1,000

options.label: D
options.text: Over 2,000

questions.question: What is the ultimate goal of the court cases and global efforts to recognize the right to a healthy environment, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To impose stricter regulations on industries

options.label: B
options.text: To provide financial compensation to affected communities

options.label: C
options.text: To give future generations a better chance to breathe clean air and live in a world with preserved natural ecosystems

options.label: D
options.text: To promote sustainable economic growth

questions.question: What action can a government take to address the issue of frequent heatwaves, longer droughts, and more destructive wildfires due to climate change, based on the concept of human rights?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase funding for disaster relief efforts

options.label: B
options.text: Implement policies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and protect the right to a healthy environment

options.label: C
options.text: Provide financial compensation to affected communities

options.label: D
options.text: Establish a national emergency response team

titles.title: How can groups make good decisions? - Mariano Sigman and Dan Ariely

questions.question: According to research, what is essential for crowds to make wise decisions?

options.label: A
options.text: Peer pressure and social media influence

options.label: B
options.text: Independent thinking

options.label: C
options.text: Simple conversations and debates

options.label: D
options.text: Publicity and large group discussions

questions.question: What was the outcome of the experiment conducted in Buenos Aires, Argentina, with over 10,000 participants?

options.label: A
options.text: Averaging individual opinions before debate was more accurate than averaging group answers after debate

options.label: B
options.text: Averaging group answers after debate was more accurate than averaging individual opinions before debate

options.label: C
options.text: There was no significant difference between averaging individual opinions and group answers

options.label: D
options.text: The experiment was inconclusive

questions.question: What type of issues did the experiment in Vancouver, Canada, focus on?

options.label: A
options.text: Simple right-or-wrong answers

options.label: B
options.text: Social and political issues

options.label: C
options.text: Moral dilemmas

options.label: D
options.text: Both B and C

questions.question: In the experiment, what was the role of "high-confident grays" in reaching a consensus?

options.label: A
options.text: They hindered the group from reaching a consensus

options.label: B
options.text: They had no significant impact on the group's decision

options.label: C
options.text: They helped the group reach a consensus by understanding the merits of both arguments

options.label: D
options.text: They dominated the discussion and imposed their opinions

questions.question: How do groups typically reach a consensus, according to the experiment's findings?

options.label: A
options.text: By taking a simple average of all answers

options.label: B
options.text: By weighing the strength of each vote based on confidence

options.label: C
options.text: By implementing a "robust average" that ignores outliers

options.label: D
options.text: By following the opinion of the most confident group member

questions.question: What are the two essential components of good collective decisions, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Deliberation and diversity of opinions

options.label: B
options.text: Voting and consensus

options.label: C
options.text: Independent thinking and peer pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Social media influence and publicity

questions.question: What is the potential benefit of forming small groups to make collective decisions?

options.label: A
options.text: It ensures everyone gets to express their voice, but may not foster thoughtful debates

options.label: B
options.text: It balances diversity of opinions and deliberation

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to more polarized opinions

options.label: D
options.text: It is only effective for simple right-or-wrong answers

questions.question: According to the speaker, what is the current limitation of the typical voting system?

options.label: A
options.text: It does not ensure diversity of opinions

options.label: B
options.text: It does not allow for thoughtful debates

options.label: C
options.text: It is not effective for complex problems

options.label: D
options.text: It is not representative of the majority's opinion

questions.question: What is the potential outcome of using science to understand how we interact and make decisions?

options.label: A
options.text: It will lead to more polarization and conflict

options.label: B
options.text: It will spark interesting new ways to construct a better democracy

options.label: C
options.text: It will have no significant impact on collective decision-making

options.label: D
options.text: It will only be effective for simple right-or-wrong answers

questions.question: What was the speaker's conclusion about the experiment's findings and their potential application?

options.label: A
options.text: The experiment's findings are conclusive and can be directly applied to real-world scenarios

options.label: B
options.text: The experiment's findings are promising, but more research is needed to understand their implications

options.label: C
options.text: The experiment's findings are inconclusive and have no practical application

options.label: D
options.text: The experiment's findings are only relevant to simple right-or-wrong answers
